required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Automatic Diagnosis of Spinal Stenosis on CT
clinical_study.official_title: Automatic Diagnosis of Spinal Stenosis on CT With Deep Learning

collaborator.agency: Shanghai Tongji Hospital, Tongji University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: MRI is a common tool for radiographic diagnosis of spinal stenosis, but it is expensive and requires long scanning time. CT is also a useful tool to diagnose spinal stenosis, yet interpretation can be time-consuming with high inter-reader variability even among the most specialized radiologists. In this study, the investigators aim to develop a deep-learning algorithm to automatically detect and classify lumbar spinal stenosis.

detailed_description.textblock: MRI is a common tool for radiographic diagnosis of spinal stenosis, but it is expensive and requires long scanning time. CT is also a useful tool to diagnose spinal stenosis, yet interpretation can be time-consuming with high inter-reader variability even among the most specialized radiologists. In this study, the investigators aim to develop a deep-learning algorithm to automatically detect and classify lumbar spinal stenosis. It would be a time-saving workflow if the software can assist the radiologists to detect and locate the suspected lesion.

primary_outcome.description: Diagnostic accuracy of deep learning to determine spinal stenosis compared with radiologists' labels based on CT

secondary_outcome.description: Sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value and negative predictive value of deep learning compared with radiologists' labels based on CT

arm_group.description: Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spaces within your spine, which can put pressure on the nerves that travel through the spine. Spinal stenosis occurs most often in the lower back and the neck.

intervention.description: detect and classify spinal stenosis by deep learning

study_pop.textblock:
Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spaces within the spine, which can put pressure on the nerves that travel through the spine. Spinal stenosis occurs most often in the back, the neck, and sometimes the thoracic spine.
Some people with spinal stenosis may not have symptoms. Others may experience pain, tingling, numbness and muscle weakness. Symptoms can worsen over time.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age >18 years
- with radiologists' CT reports on cervical, thoracic and lumbar stenosis
Exclusion Criteria:
- not applicable (only specific levels with extensive infections, fractures, tumor, high-grade spondylolisthesis would be excluded for analysis).
